content:
I do not believe this can be done in Reverse Mode without a Chemistry background.
Edit: removed the Reverse Mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a nice puzzle for testing switch statement. It is not easy to create a code-clash for switch, so the puzzle is quite unique. After solving the puzzle I learnt two new things:
- in python there is no switch (AFAIK), 
- one can solve the puzzle using dictionaries (maps), like below:
prefix_switcher = {
    1 : "mon",
    2: "di",
    3: "tri",
    4: "tetr",
    5: "pent"
}
This dictionary (map) solution for switch looks good to me, so 
maybe it can be used in other languages such as java and javascript

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a well-rounded contribution.

This clash had enough issues where I almost rejected it. I hope you don't mind that instead I went in and made several corrections to approve it. Because in truth, I'm really hoping for it to succeed.

Language and organization was a big one for me, but probably more important if you want to be able to play Reverse is enough samples to draw from, since the validators are hidden. I also fixed the default stub.

I am satisfied that the original intent is preserved, despite the degree of change. If you feel otherwise, please feel free to alter further. Hopefully you agree that overall it's an improvement, even if there may be additional tweaks here and there.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Hello thienphuc-dev :-)

I like your statement, it is feasible and we can easily reduce the size of the code (I coded my solution in python).

I noticed that your starting code was not functional in Java:
```java
for (int i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
  String x = in.nextLine(); // 2 lines of inputs
}
int oxideNum = in.nextInt(); // 1 line of input
```

I edited the stub generator to get the first line and then the second.
```java
String nometal = in.nextLine(); // we just have to split
int oxideNum = in.nextInt();
```
Seems good, pretty cool to me
If the values of the dictionary are functions, then calling the value referenced by a key effectively acts as a switch. But no, it's not built into the python syntax.
me too and I ALREADY removed Reverse Mode when publish this
Then someone else must have turned it on. D:
